Graphical abstract Heterojunction engineering is crucial for converting glycerol into valuable organic compounds via photoelectrochemistry, but controlling the structure precisely to enhance conversion efficiency remains challenging. In this study, we effectively created a compound photoanode with unique active regions by growing amorphous FeOOH co-catalysts on BiVO4. The results revealed that the Fe2+ ions located on the surface of the co-catalyst FeOOH facilitate the glycerol transformation process, whereas the electron-rich Bi-O-Fe sites contribute significantly to the preferential transformation of glycerol into glyceraldehyde. These sites not only serve as primary reactive centers, catalyzing the adsorption and conversion of glycerol hydroxyl clusters, but also act as repositories for trapping holes. This dual function accelerates the breaking of CH bonds to generate glycerol aldehyde and exhibits excellent desorption capacity, ensuring exceptional product selectivity. This led to exceptional glyceraldehyde production (709mmol m-2 h−1) compared to pristine BiVO4, showcasing a 14.98-fold increase. Keywords BiVO4 Co-catalyst Glycerol oxidation Glyceraldehyde Photoelectrochemical Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Biodiesel is considered a renewable, biodegradable, non-toxic and environmentally friendly green fuel that can replace traditional diesel [1,2]. However, with the rapid growth of the biodiesel industry, a significant amount of surplus glycerol (GLY) is generated as a by-product, leading to an excess of GLY that urgently requires conversion into high-value chemicals [3,4]. Glycerol is a highly functionalized molecule with three hydroxyl groups, making it an extremely potential platform compound [5]. Through catalytic oxidation pathways, glycerol can be converted into a variety of high value-added chemicals, such as glyceraldehyde (GLAD), dihydroxyacetone (DHA), glyceric acid (GLA), and formic acid (FA) [6]. Photocatalytic-electrocatalytic (PEC) methods have attracted considerable attention in recent years due to their remarkable capability in achieving highly efficient GLY conversion [7,8]. This approach synergistically integrates the benefits of photocatalysis and electrocatalysis, providing not only simplified equipment and reduced costs but also facilitating the straightforward separation of catalysts from products, thus attracting broad attention. Nevertheless, the production of valuable compounds from GLY through oxidation demands the activation of termina and construct surface-active sites that facilitate the adsorption and activatiol and intermediate hydroxyl sites, the continuous oxidation of CH and OH bonds, and the inhibition of CC bond breakage [9–11]. Therefore, the strategic development of a proficient GLY oxidation catalyst with selective bond cleavage abilities towards specific chemical moieties in the GLY framework is particularly important. It is widely recognized that the surface of a catalyst plays a pivotal role in driving the advancement of chemical reactions [12]. Likewise, GLY oxidation occurring at the catalyst surface follows this fundamental principle. In general, the surfaces of most photoanode exhibit restricted activity for GLY oxidation and limited selectivity towards specific substances. Therefore, it is an effective way to enhance catalytic performance by reasonably designing and controllably constructing surface-active sites that match the adsorption and activation modes of reactant molecules according to the characteristics and requirements of the target reaction [13–16]. Moreover, this also provides new ideas for the activation of polyols and the cleavage of specific molecular bonds. Previous studies have demonstrated that the modification of photoanode catalysts with supported co-catalysts can significantly enhance the activity of surface sites [17,18]. This not only retains the excellent properties of each surface but also induces high-activity sites that provide sufficient space for reactions occurring at the interface. Fundamental theoretical research also reveals that crucial elementary steps in catalytic reactions entail the intricate interplay between reactants and the active centers located at the interface of the catalyst. These steps encompass the adsorption of reactants, diffusion and migration of intermediates, and the adsorption as well as dissociation of product molecules [19,20]. By excluding solute and heat conduction, along with other irrelevant influencing factors, the structure of active centers assumes a pivotal role in dictating both the direction and magnitude of chemical reactions [21]. Therefore, accurately identifying favorable interfacial active sites and optimizing their properties is particularly important for further studying the relationship between the microstructure of surface-active sites and catalyst performance [22,23]. The strategic modification of photoanode catalysts, such as BiVO4, with co-catalysts is known to substantially boost the reactivity of surface sites [24,25]. This enhancement is crucial for optimizing the photoelectrochemical performance of BiVO4, which is already recognized for its inherent properties conducive to light absorption and charge separation [26,27]. While BiVO4 has been utilized in photoelectrocatalytic glycerol transformation [28,29], investigations into the synergistic mechanisms of co-catalysts remain limited and have not been extensively explored. In this study, an in-situ growth method was employed to successfully load the multivalent FeOOH co-catalyst onto the surface of BiVO4. By means of both experimental and theoretical calculations, the unsaturated Fe species induced by the Bi substrate were precisely determined to be the active centers responsible for GLY oxidation. More specifically, a thin amorphous layer of FeOOH co-catalyst was deliberately deposited onto the surface of BiVO4 using an in-situ modification method. Under AM1.5G (100mW m−2) light intensity with an applied bias of 1.23 V vs. RHE, the GLAD production rate reached 709mmol m−2 h−1 with a selectivity of 63.3 %. Moreover, the catalyst exhibited exceptional long-term stability throughout 10 consecutive GLY oxidation cycles. The experimental and computational findings unveiled that the presence of Bi at the p-n junction interface, established between FeOOH and BiVO4, effectively modulated the surface electronic structure of FeOOH, leading to the generation of Bi-O-Fe active sites. These active sites not only facilitated the adsorption of GLY but also facilitated the migration of photogenerated holes from the bulk to the surface, thereby actively participating in subsequent GLY oxidation reactions. Analysis conducted using Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR) and Density Functional Theory (DFT) demonstrated that the Bi-O-Fe active sites exhibited a preference for adsorbing hydroxyl groups at the terminal site of GLY, thereby promoting the selective conversion of GLY into GLAD. Furthermore, it was found that the reaction kinetics of GLY in the PEC glycerol oxidation process were predominantly governed by the photogenerated holes (primary active species), rather than the electrophilic ·OH species (secondary active species). This study elucidated the pivotal role played by surface active site microstructures in dictating the performance of GLY oxidation, thereby offering valuable insights to tackle the prominent scientific hurdle of enhancing catalyst activity and selectivity through the implementation of surface engineering strategies in future endeavors. 2 Experimental details 2.1 Materials and reagents All chemicals, unless otherwise specified, were utilized without additional refinement. The following chemicals were procured from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd., with their respective chemical formulas and purities noted: Potassium iodide (KI, ≥99 %), Glycerol (GLY, C3H8O3, ≥99 %), bismuth nitrate pentahydrate (Bi(NO3)3·5H2O, 99 %), p-benzoquinone (C6H4O2, 97 %), vanadium acetylacetonate (VO(acac)2, purity not specified), iron(III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O, 99 %), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, purity not specified), ethanol (C2H5OH, purity not specified), nitric acid (HNO3, purity not specified), and sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 99 %). FTO substrates (FTO, 7 Ω, light transmittance 90 %, active area 10 × 30 × 2.2 mm) were obtained from Nippon Sheet Glass Co. The FTO conductive glass underwent meticulous cleaning using ultrasonic agitation with acetone (C3H6O, purity not specified), ethanol (C2H5OH, purity not specified), and deionized water). 2.2 Preparation of nanoporous BiVO4 photoanodes Nanoporous BiVO4 photoanodes were fabricated in accordance with previously documented methodologies (Scheme 1 , Step 1 and 2). In a standard synthetic procedure, 1.46 g of Bi(NO3)3·5H2O was dissolved in a KI solution (4.98 g, 75 mL). Subsequent addition of an HNO3 solution facilitated adjustment of the pH to 1.7. This solution was then combined with 30 mL of ethanol containing 0.747 g of p-benzoquinone, and vigorously stirred for 30 min to yield the electrodeposition solution. Electrodeposition was performed utilizing a conventional three-electrode configuration, comprising an FTO working electrode (WE), an Ag/AgCl reference electrode (RE) with 4 M KCl, and a platinum pair counter electrode (CE). Cathodic deposition was conducted under a constant potential of −0.1 V vs. Ag/AgCl for 300 s at room temperature to produce the BiOI electrodes. Subsequently, BiOI electrodes underwent coating with 0.53 g of VO (acac)2 dissolved in a 10 mL DMSO solution, followed by annealing in air for 2 h in a muffle furnace (HF-Kejing Furnace, KSL-1100X) at 450 °C (ramping rate = 2 °C/min) to undergo transformation into BiVO4. Post-calcination, electrodes were immersed in a 1 M NaOH solution for 10 min to eliminate excess V2O5. The resulting pure BiVO4 electrodes were thoroughly rinsed with deionized water and air-dried prior to further analysis. The surface morphology of the prepared BiOI and BiVO4 is shown in Fig. S1. 2.3 Preparation of nanoporous FeOOH-x/BiVO4 photoanodes The as-prepared BiVO4 electrodes were immersed in a solution of FeCl3·6H2O (5, 10, 20, and 30 mM, 20 mL) for 30 min. Following this, a NaOH (1 M) solution was introduced to adjust the pH level to slightly alkaline conditions (∼8) through gentle stirring over a 5-minute duration. Subsequently, the solution was allowed to stand for 1 h. Lastly, the electrodes underwent rinsing with deionized water and were subjected to blow-drying to yield FeOOH-x/BiVO4 (x = 5, 10, 20, and 30) samples (Scheme 1, Step 3). 2.4 Characterization The morphological characteristics of the samples were investigated via field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, TESCAN MIRA3 LMH) operating at an acceleration voltage of 10 kV. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) analyses were executed utilizing a field emission transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL2100F) with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV, complemented by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) for sample characterization. X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku Smartlab) was utilized for sample examination, employing Cu Kα radiation within the 2θ range of 20 to 80 degrees. Valence states and elemental compositions of the samples were determined through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi) utilizing Al-Kα radiation. UV–visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy was carried out using a PerkinElmer Lambda 750 UV–vis spectrometer, with BaSO4 serving as the reference material. Analysis of electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was performed employing a Brucker EPR A 200 W spectrometer. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were acquired using an FLS980 fluorometer manufactured by Edinburgh Instruments Ltd. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectral investigation was completed using an IR Affinity-1 FTIR spectrometer (Shimadzu, Japan). 2.5 PEC measurements To assess the electrochemical characteristics, a three-electrode setup connected to a Metrohm Autolab (PGSTAT302N) electrochemical workstation was employed. A range of examinations was carried out, encompassing Transient Photocurrent Spectroscopy (I-t) for photocurrent evaluation and reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) set at 0.5588 V, Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) was performed at a potential of 0.5588 V versus the Reversible Hydrogen Electrode (RHE), while Linear Sweep Voltammetry (LSV) tests were conducted over a potential range from −0.5 to 1.0 V versus Ag/AgCl. These electrochemical measurements were carried out on standalone photoanodes under conditions that included the presence of 0.1 M glycerol. It should be noted that all potential values mentioned in this study have been converted to RHE potentials, as detailed in Eq. (1): (1) E RHE = E Ag/Ag/Cl + 0.059 pH + 0.1976 The incident photon-to-current conversion efficiencies (IPCE) were determined using a PLS-MC300 monochromator in conjunction with a PLX-SXE300 xenon lamp. The formula utilized for calculating IPCE was outlined below: (2) IPCE = 1240 / λ · J light - J dark P × 100 % In the equation, λ represents the wavelength, Jlight signifies the density under irradiation, Jdark denotes the density under dark conditions, and P stands for the incident light power density. Assuming a Faradaic efficiency of 100 %, the applied bias photon-to-current efficiency (ABPE) was determined using the following equation: (3) A B P E % = I mA/cm 2 × 1023 - V bias V P light mW/cm 2 × 100 % Here, I represent the photocurrent density, V bias denotes the applied potential, and P light stands for the incident illumination power density set at (100 mW cm−2). 2.6 Evaluation of PEC glycerol oxidation In accordance with standard reaction conditions, the photoelectrode anode was submersed in an H-type quartz electrolytic cell housing a 0.1 M Na2SO4 aqueous solution supplemented with an additional 0.1 M GLY. The solution underwent continuous stirring at a speed of 500 revolutions per minute. Subsequently, the oxidation process was executed in the presence of AM 1.5G irradiation (100 mW cm−2) over a duration of 2 h, with a consistent potential set at 1.23 V vs. RHE, all while maintaining the ambient temperature (298 K). The selectivity of A can be evaluated utilizing the forthcoming equation: (4) Selectivity A = n A n GLAD + n DHA + n GLA + n FA + n Others × 100 % Compute the rate of production (or consumption) of A based on the subsequent equation: (5) Formation r a t e A = n A t × A r e a × 100 % Here, t denotes the reaction time in hours, while Area represents the surface area of the photoelectric anode in square meters. For simulating solar light exposure, a 300 W xenon lamp was employed alongside an AM 1.5G filter (100 mW cm−2). The light intensity from the Xenon lamp, equipped with an AM 1.5G filter to simulate solar illumination, was set at 100 mW cm−2 for all PEC measurements (Fig. S2). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 PEC and glycerol conversion performance By immersing pure BiVO4 photoanodes in a FeCl3·6H2O solution with various molar concentrations for 30 min, followed by soaking in NaOH with a pH of 8 for an additional hour, FeOOH-x/BiVO4 (x is the concentration of FeCl3·6H2O used) with varying FeOOH loading can be obtained. The PEC oxidation ability of different FeOOH-x/BiVO4 composite photoanodes was assessed for GLY oxidation under simulated solar illumination in a solution comprising 0.1 M Na2SO4 and 0.1 M GLY first. All FeOOH-x/BiVO4 composite photoanodes have much better performance in glycerol oxidation than pure BiVO4 (Fig. S3). The FeOOH-10/BiVO4 sample had the highest photocurrent density at 4.5 mA cm−2, which is 3.75 times higher than the 1.2 mA cm−2 of BiVO4. This makes FeOOH-10/BiVO4 the best photocatalyst for this use. The right amount of FeOOH is key to maximizing the interaction with BiVO4 and improving the photocatalyst's performance. Too little FeOOH might not interact enough, while too much could block active sites (Fig. S4). The term “FeOOH/BiVO4″ from now on refers to the FeOOH-10/BiVO4 photoanode. Fig. 1 a displays the LSV curves for pure BiVO4, pure FeOOH, and FeOOH/BiVO4 composite photoanodes. FeOOH/BiVO4 showed the highest photocurrent density within the potential range of 0.3–1.3 V vs. RHE, indicating the effective promotion of PEC performance of BiVO4 by incorporated FeOOH. Introduction of GLY to the electrolyte enhanced photocurrent densities of all catalysts due to lower reaction barrier compared to water oxidation [30,31]. It is noteworthy that pure FeOOH samples exhibited considerably low photocurrent density regardless of the presence of GLY, thereby emphasizing the significance of introducing FeOOH co-catalysts on BiVO4 in the PEC glycerol oxidation process. FeOOH/BiVO4 achieved the highest IPCE value (66 %) at 420 nm wavelength and ABPE value of 1.80 %, surpassing that of pure BiVO4 by a factor of 3.75, as presented in Fig. 2 b and c respectively. Subsequently, high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) was employed to identify the oxidation products of GLY on the various photoanodes. The FeOOH-modified BiVO4 samples demonstrated exceptionally impressive performance in GLY oxidation As (Fig. S3b). Specifically, the FeOOH-10/BiVO4 photoanode achieved the highest GLY conversion rate, reaching 1120mmol m-2h−1, and a conversion efficiency of 2.8 % within one hour. The performance is significantly higher than that of pure FeOOH and BiVO4, with enhancement factors of 18.67 and 6.36 for the conversion rate and efficiency, respectively. It is noteworthy that the GLY conversion rate initially increases with the loading amount of FeOOH and then declines, which is in line with the observed photocurrent densities (Fig. S3c). This trend suggests that an optimal loading amount of FeOOH is crucial for maximizing the catalytic activity. Furthermore, within a 3-hour period, the FeOOH-10/BiVO4 photoanode also displayed the highest rate of hydrogen production (Fig. S3d). As previously mentioned, this behavior may be due to an excessive concentration of FeOOH leading to extensive coverage (Fig. S4), which hinders the exposure of active sites at the heterojunction interface between FeOOH and BiVO4, thereby reducing the adsorption of GLY on the catalyst surface [32]. Additionally, Fig. 1d and 1e illustrate that the inclusion of FeOOH loading not only boosts the rate of GLY conversion but also exhibits exceptional selectivity towards GLAD, with significantly increased production rates: 63.3 % and 709mmol m-2h−1, respectively. These rates are considerably higher than those achieved by FeOOH (42.7 %; 25.62mmol m-2h−1) and BiVO4 (26.9 %; 47.34mmol m-2h−1). Furthermore, both BiVO4 and FeOOH exhibit a tendency for the overoxidation of GLY, predominantly yielding GLA (glyceric acid) and FA (formic acid) as byproducts, thus offering more proof for the substantial influence of loading co-catalysts on BiVO4 on GLY oxidation and product selectivity. In addition, Fig. 1f demonstrates that the FeOOH/BiVO4 photoanode maintains excellent selectivity towards GLAD, even as the GLY conversion rates continue to rise. This selectivity is sustained over a 10-hour period, during which the GLY conversion rate of FeOOH/BiVO4 reaches around 37 %, exhibiting a clear positive correlation with time. These results highlight the remarkable catalytic effect of the composite photoanode on GLY oxidation. Finally, a comprehensive assessment of the stability of the composite photoanode was performed by conducting product selectivity measurements for a total of 10 cycles (Fig. 1g). Even after completing 10 cycles, the selectivity of GLAD remained consistently high at approximately 63.0 %, which can be ascribed to the exceptional structural stability of the composite photoanode, as demonstrated in Fig. S5. Increasing the applied potential resulted in higher GLY conversion rates while maintaining constant selectivity towards GLAD at around 60 %. A bias of 1.23 V exhibited the best selectivity for GLAD (Fig. S6), hence a standardized oxidation potential of 1.23 V is used in subsequent investigations unless otherwise stated. 3.2 Morphology and structural analysis The results above unequivocally demonstrate that incorporating the FeOOH cocatalyst onto BiVO4 significantly boosts the efficiency of glycerol photoelectrochemical oxidation and enhances the selectivity for GLAD. Both the efficiency and selectivity are closely associated with the loading amount of FeOOH. The remarkable PEC performance of GLY oxidation is profoundly connected to the complex morphology and precisely engineered crystal structure of the photoanode material. For thorough investigation into the impact of the composite structure on the complex GLY conversion process, we systematically characterize the morphology and phase structure of the composite photoanode, taking FeOOH-10/BiVO4 as an example. The SEM images in Fig. 2a to d offer a detailed surfaces morphology of the pure BiVO4 and the FeOOH/BiVO4 composite photoanode. The lower magnification images suggest a similar morphology between the pristine BiVO4 and the composite photoanode (Fig. 2a and c). Upon close inspection of the high-magnification images in Fig. 2b and d, the pure BiVO4 has a compact, worm-like structure measuring 100 to 200 nm across. In comparison, the FeOOH/BiVO4 composite shows a fluffy surface layer not present in the pure BiVO4. This layer is believed to be FeOOH coating the BiVO4, suggesting successful co-catalyst incorporation. It is important to note that loading FeOOH directly onto FTO via the same method results in a granular morphology (Fig. S7). This granular form hinders the effective deposition of FeOOH on the FTO surface, leading to a reduced photocurrent response from the FeOOH (as shown in Fig. 1). The TEM image in Fig. 2e displays the worm-like structure of the FeOOH/BiVO4 composite photoanode, along with a distinct amorphous layer (highlighted in red) representing the FeOOH. The SAED pattern reveals the presence of a monoclinic BiVO4 phase, showcasing crystal planes such as (01−3), (−202), and (−21−1), which align with the [131] crystallographic zone axis. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of FeOOH/BiVO4, as presented in Fig. 2f and Fig. S8, exhibited a uniformly amorphous and thin layer with a thickness varying from 2 to 10 nm, providing evidence for the formation of a thin FeOOH nanolayer on the surface of the BiVO4 photoanode. The lattice spacing of 0.474 nm can be attributed to the (110) crystal plane of monoclinic BiVO4, whereas no discernible lattice pattern was observed for the FeOOH nanolayer, which is consistent with the SAED results shown in Fig. 2e. The STEM-EDS mapping results depicted in Fig. 2g provided compelling evidence showcasing the uniform distribution of Bi, V, O, and Fe elements throughout the entire photoelectrode, thereby confirming the successful loading and encapsulation of the FeOOH nanolayer within BiVO4. The increase in the Fe source content resulted in a higher concentration of the cocatalyst, subsequently inducing surface roughness on BiVO4 and the formation of aggregated excess FeOOH cocatalyst (Fig. S4). According to the data presented in Table S1, the concentration of the Fe element increased from 0.6 At% in FeOOH-5/BiVO4 to 1.4 At% in FeOOH-30/BiVO4. The XRD patterns depicted in Fig. 2h and Fig. S9 exhibited distinctive peaks that corresponded to the monoclinic structure of BiVO4 in FeOOH/BiVO4 photoelectrodes. In comparison to pristine BiVO4, no significant diffraction peaks corresponding to the FeOOH co-catalyst were observed, primarily attributed to its amorphous structure, ultra-thin thickness, and high dispersion on BiVO4, consistent with the results obtained from TEM analysis. Fig. 2i displays the infrared spectroscopic analysis for pure FeOOH, pure BiVO4, and the composite FeOOH/BiVO4 material. The spectral peaks at 3333 and 1648 cm−1 are indicative of OH vibrations, whereas the peaks at 2972 and 2884 cm−1 correspond to the stretching vibrations of Fe-O bonds. The signature peak at 884 cm−1 is associated with the bending mode of Fe-OH, 809 cm−1 with the VO stretching mode, 656 cm−1 with Fe-O vibrations, and 566 cm−1 with the Bi-O stretching mode [33–36]. Upon comparison between BiVO4 and FeOOH/BiVO4 photoelectrodes, it is observed that the Fe-OH bond in the FeOOH/BiVO4 composite exhibits negligible variation. In contrast, both the FeO and BiO bonds in the composite have experienced considerable alterations in peak shape and intensity. Additionally, the emergence of new peaks within the spectrum (highlighted in the purple region of the figure) suggests the presence of interactions between Fe and Bi atoms, which may be responsible for these observed spectral changes. Fig. 2j displays noticeable alterations in the intensity of vibrational bands in FeOOH/BiVO4 photoanodes under low-intensity red light (785 nm) excitation, compared to pristine BiVO4. Characteristic vibrational bands of both BiVO4 and FeOOH were identified at different frequencies. The characteristic peaks located at 210, 324, 366, 640, 710, and 826 cm−1 are attributed to BiVO4. Pure FeOOH is identified by its characteristic peaks at 188 and 331 cm−1 [37]. However, for the FeOOH/BiVO4 composite electrode, in addition to the characteristic peaks of BiVO4 that can be detected, the original characteristic peaks of FeOOH have disappeared. Instead, new characteristic peaks have emerged at 250 and 382 cm−1, which are associated with Bi-O-Fe [38–40]. Nevertheless, using a higher-energy 532 nm laser caused the disappearance of characteristic peaks related to FeOOH, likely due to the laser's ability to penetrate and disrupt the amorphous FeOOH layer. As a result, no characteristic Raman bands were observed for Bi-O-Fe, indicating that the structural integrity of this component was compromised under high-energy excitation. Additionally, examination of the full XPS spectra in Fig. S10 for the pristine BiVO4, FeOOH and the FeOOH/BiVO4 photoanodes reveals the distinctive presence of Fe in the FeOOH/BiVO4 composite and FeOOH. This detection exclusively in the composite material serves as a compelling indication of the successful integration of the ultra-thin FeOOH co-catalyst layer onto the BiVO4 surface. Fig. 2l and m present the XPS peaks for both Bi and Fe elements in FeOOH/BiVO4 and their respective pure forms. The Bi 4f peak in FeOOH/BiVO4 has moved 0.3 eV higher in binding energy compared to BiVO4 (as seen in Fig. 2l), while the Fe 2p peak has shifted 1.4 eV lower in energy compared to pure FeOOH (as shown in Fig. 2m) [41]. These shifts indicate strong interactions between FeOOH and BiVO4, altering their electronic structures and chemical environments. The higher binding energy shift for Bi suggests changes in its local environment due to the presence of FeOOH, possibly from new coordination or charge transfer. The lower binding energy shift for Fe suggests changes in its oxidation state or bonding in the composite, likely due to the effect of BiVO4 on electronic properties of FeOOH, possibly enhanced by the formation of Bi-O-Fe at the interface [38]. This could lead to more reactive sites for glycerol oxidation, boosting the catalytic activity of the composite photoanodes. Fig. S11 demonstrate that the valence state of V remains largely unaffected by the presence of FeOOH, in line with earlier studies [38]. 3.3 Study on catalyst surface properties and glycerol conversion performance Previous research studies have provided evidence for the presence of strong charge interactions at the heterojunction interface, which could potentially lead to the generation of extra reactive sites [42–44]. Consequently, XPS was utilized for precise spectral fitting of Fe 2p spectrum and distinguish between the different states that are present. Owing to the remarkable sensitivity of Fe 2p XPS peak positions to the oxidation state of Fe, a quantitative assessment of the impact of BiVO4 on FeOOH via peak fitting can be achieved. Furthermore, the thinness of FeOOH in these samples allows XPS probing to reach BiVO4, indicating that the diverse Fe species states obtained through XPS cover the entire FeOOH layer. As illustrated in Fig. 3 a, pure FeOOH presents two different states of Fe species as Fe3+ (712.4 eV) and Fe2+ (710.1 eV) at a ratio of 44:56. Upon analysis of the FeOOH-x/BiVO4 composite photoanodes, the peak at 711.1 eV is identified as a signature of the Bi-O-Fe bond. This peak arises due to the electron transfer from Bi to Fe when FeOOH is in contact with BiVO4, as evidenced by computational results shown in Fig. 3b and 3c. This electron transfer suggests that Bi significantly impacts the higher-valence iron species, especially Fe3+. After Fe3+ accepts an electron from Bi, its degree of saturation is reduced, which is reflected in the XPS spectrum by a shift towards lower binding energy. Nonetheless, this shift does not match the level of unsaturation characteristic of Fe2+. Therefore, the higher-valence iron species, which have been altered through interaction with Bi, exhibit binding energies in the XPS spectrum that fall between those associated with Fe3+ and Fe2+. The proportion of Fe2+ remains relatively constant in different FeOOH-x/BiVO4 composite photoanodes despite variations in the FeOOH loading amount. These results offer compelling evidence that the Bi-O-Fe interaction sites, which are a result of the combined action of BiVO4 and FeOOH, facilitate the efficient and selective transformation of GLY into GLAD. To substantiate the XPS findings and clarify the mechanisms of electronic interactions at the interface, we conducted calculations using density functional theory (DFT). The visual representation of the charge density difference between BiVO4 and FeOOH in Fig. 3b and c strikingly captures the dynamics of charge transfer and accumulation. Bader charge analysis has quantified this transfer, revealing a significant electron exchange occurring specifically between the Bi, O, and Fe atoms at the interface. This is manifested by electron depletion at Bi (indicated in blue) and an accumulation of electrons at Fe (shown in yellow), offering theoretical validation for the formation of BiOFe bonds [45–47]. The Bader charge analysis has quantified this transfer, showing a charge movement of 5.43e from BiVO4 to FeOOH. This finding aligns with prior research suggesting electron migration from Bi to Fe at the heterojunction interface. As a result, BiVO4, under light exposure, acts as a photosensitive material, generating excited electrons and holes. The regions within the Bi-O-Fe structure that are rich in electrons efficiently promote the migration of holes from BiVO4. These holes, with their high oxidative potential, are poised to engage in the oxidation of glycerol. Fig. 3e demonstrates a correlation between the proportion of Bi-O-Fe bonds determined by XPS and the glycerol conversion rate and GLAD selectivity. As expected, as the proportion of Bi-O-Fe bonds increases, both the glycerol conversion rate and GLAD selectivity increase, indicating a positive correlation between the glycerol conversion rate and selectivity and the ratio of Bi-O-Fe. This indicates that the unique Bi-O-Fe sites formed at the heterojunction interface may serve as a significant factor that causes the observed differences in performance before and after catalyst modification. To verify this, FeOOH/BiVO4 underwent oxidation and reduction processes utilizing H2O2 and NaHB4, respectively, with the aim of manipulating the ratio of Fe3+, Bi-O-Fe and Fe2+. As illustrated in Fig. 3d, following the oxidation treatment, the Fe3+: Bi-O-Fe: Fe2+ ratios stand at 45:31:24, manifesting notable declines in the Bi-O-Fe and Fe2+ proportions. Consequently, there is a substantial decrease in both the GLY conversion rate and the GLAD selectivity (Fig. 3f). Following the reduction procedure in a NaHB4 solution, the Fe3+: BiOFe: Fe2+ ratio transitions to 18:40:42. Notably, the BiOFe composition experiences a modest decrease, shifting from 41 % to 40 %, while conversely, the Fe2+ content exhibits an elevation from 39 % to 42 %. Consequently, GLAD selectivity marginally declines to 96 % from its initial level, while GLY conversion sees a notable 25 % enhancement (Fig. 3f). Therefore, this confirms that the exceptional selectivity observed in the conversion of GLY into GLAD is influenced by the existence of unsaturated Bi-O-Fe sites formed at heterojunction interfaces. Subsequently, a more meticulous approach was taken where the BiVO4/FeOOH composite underwent high-temperature annealing to eliminate all present Bi-O-Fe active sites. This procedure confirmed the exceptional preference of these sites towards GLAD. As depicted in Fig. S12a, after high-temperature annealing at 500 °C for 2 h, all BiVO4/FeOOH transformed into Fe2O3/BiVO4. It is noteworthy that there were no visible traces of Bi-O-Fe in the annealed photoanode, and all iron species were entirely oxidized to the Fe3+ state. As expected, the annealed photoanode exhibited almost identical levels of GLY conversion efficiency and GLAD selectivity compared to pristine BiVO4 (Fig. S12b). All the above findings effectively confirm that Fe2+ ions present on the surface of the co-catalyst FeOOH facilitate the GLY transformation process, while the unoccupied Bi-O-Fe sites significantly contribute to the selective conversion of GLY into GLAD. 3.4 Formation of the p-n junction between FeOOH and BiVO4 The composite photoanode demonstrates a significantly elevated GLY conversion rate and enhanced GLAD selectivity. Apart from being influenced by the surface-active sites, the correlation between the appropriate band structure and exceptional carrier dynamics is crucial. Consequently, an in-depth investigation was undertaken to explore the band structure and carrier dynamics of FeOOH and BiVO4. The ultraviolet–visible (UV–Vis) diffuse reflectance spectroscopy results in Fig. 4 a demonstrate that pure BiVO4 has the capability to efficiently absorb visible light, as evidenced by the absorption edge at 515 nm, owing to its relatively low band gap energy of the monoclinic scheelite BiVO4 phase (2.48 eV, see Fig. 4a inset). This observation is in line with prior studies [48]. FeOOH/BiVO4 displays a red shift absorption edge at 534 nm, indicating a band gap energy of 2.4 eV, which demonstrates that FeOOH functions as a photosensitizer, allowing for extended visible light absorption. The UV–Vis spectrum of pure FeOOH further corroborates these findings, exhibiting an absorption edge located at 558 nm and indicating a band gap energy of 2.27 eV (inset of Fig. 4a). Increasing the loading quantity of FeOOH amplifies the degree of red shift in the FeOOH/BiVO4 photoanodes (Fig. S13a). The Mott-Schottky curves of BiVO4 (Fig. S13b,) manifest a positive slope and illustrate a flatband potential of 0.37 eV. In contrast, the M−S curve of FeOOH (Fig. S13c) exhibits a negative slope along with a flatband potential of 1.48 eV. These results suggest that BiVO4 can be categorized as an n-type semiconductor, whereas FeOOH can be classified as a p-type semiconductor. The substantial disparity in Fermi energy levels (Ef) between p-type FeOOH and n-type BiVO4 leads to the formation of a p-n junction upon their contact, thereby generating a formidable electric field at the interface of FeOOH and BiVO4. Consequently, this enables efficient transfer of photogenerated holes from the valence band (VB) of BiVO4 to FeOOH, subsequently promoting GLY oxidation on FeOOH (Fig. 4b). Furthermore, The FeOOH-x/BiVO4 composites, especially the FeOOH-10/BiVO4 sample, demonstrate a decreased slope in the M−S plots, indicating increased carrier concentration, which is crucial for improved photocatalytic performance due to the p-n junction formed between BiVO4 and FeOOH (Fig. S13d). The formation of a p-n junction on the FeOOH/BiVO4 photoanode was further confirmed through Photoluminescence (PL) testing. As depicted in Fig. 4c, the introduction of FeOOH co-catalyst resulted in a notable decrease in luminescence intensity. This decrease can be attributed to the suppression of electron-hole recombination on the FeOOH/BiVO4 surface, facilitated by the presence of the p-n junction. This observation holds true across various loadings of FeOOH/BiVO4, as illustrated in Fig. S14a. Additionally, transient photocurrent curves clearly exhibit a significant reduction in the transient peak values of all FeOOH co-catalyzed BiVO4 samples at 1.23 V vs. RHE, compared to the pristine BiVO4 counterpart when using a Na2SO4 solution containing 0.1 M GLY as the electrolyte, as shown in Fig. S14b. This indicates a substantial enhancement in charge transfer efficiency and surface reactions upon the incorporation of the co-catalyst FeOOH in the composite photoanode. Comprehensive investigations were also carried out involving the determination of the bulk charge separation efficiency (ηspe) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements performed on all the investigated samples. In comparison with the pristine BiVO4, the incorporation of FeOOH into the BiVO4 resulted in a notable enhancement in the bulk charge separation efficiency (Fig. S14c) and a substantial reduction in the resistance associated with interfacial charge transfer processes (Fig. S14d). Remarkably, the FeOOH-10/BiVO4 photoanode showcased an outstanding ηsep value of 83.4 % (Fig. 4d), demonstrating an impressive enhancement of nearly threefold compared to the efficiency exhibited by the pure BiVO4 photoanode (29.7 %, Fig. 4d). Simultaneously, when compared to pure BiVO4, all FeOOH-x/BiVO4 photoanode demonstrated a notable reduction in the arc radii observed in the impedance plots (Fig. S14d). The FeOOH-10/BiVO4 exhibiting the highest level of performance, showcased the most minimal arc radius among all samples in the EIS impedance plot (Fig. 4e). These findings suggest that the introduction of FeOOH can significantly improve the efficiency of charge carrier separation in the photoanode, leading to a decrease in the resistance at the interface between the photoanode surface and the electrolyte. Consequently, this beneficial effect promotes the conversion of GLY. 3.5 Effect of FeOOH in promoting glycerol selective adsorption As depicted in Fig. 1, the primary products of GLY oxidation are typically GLAD. GLAD forms through terminal hydroxyl group oxidation of GLY upon its catalyst surface adsorption, while DHA production relates to the intermediate hydroxyl group adsorption. The investigation of GLAD selectivity during GLY oxidation on the FeOOH/BiVO4 catalyst was conducted using Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). During the testing process, we immersed powders of BiVO4, FeOOH, and FeOOH/BiVO4 in a glycerol or glyceraldehyde solution in situ. A standard quantity of photoanode material (approximately 100 mg) was introduced into a mixed solution of 0.1 M Na2SO4 with either 0.1 M glycerol or glyceraldehyde to ensure uniform adsorption. The mixture was applied to clean glass slides and dried in a desiccator for 48 h. The samples were then removed from the glass, stored in 10 mL vials, and their FTIR spectra were recorded using a Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrophotometer to analyze the adsorption of water, glycerol, and glyceraldehyde. As shown in Fig. 5 a, the interaction between GLY and the catalyst surface can be characterized by the wavenumber changes of the terminal hydroxyl groups. On FeOOH or FeOOH/BiVO4 catalysts, the adsorption of GLY leads to a significant decrease in the wavenumber of the terminal hydroxyl groups, from 1050 c-1 to 1044 or 1039 cm−1. This change indicates that FeOOH has a stronger binding capacity for the terminal hydroxyl groups of GLY. In contrast, the wavenumber change on the BiVO4 catalyst is smaller, which may imply that BiVO4 has a weaker adsorption capacity for terminal hydroxyl groups. Regarding the adsorption of intermediate hydroxyl groups, the significant shift of the characteristic spectral bands to lower wavenumbers on BiVO4 indicates a notable interaction with the intermediate hydroxyl groups. This contrasts with the smaller changes observed on FeOOH or FeOOH/BiVO4, showing a relatively weaker adsorption capacity for intermediate hydroxyl groups. Since GLAD is transformed from the terminal hydroxyl groups adsorbed on the catalyst surface, this provides a reasonable explanation for the high selectivity of FeOOH/BiVO4 for GLAD. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 5b, the study of the adsorption behavior of GLAD on different photoanode surfaces indicates that the characteristic spectra on FeOOH or FeOOH/BiVO4 (1648 or 1649 cm−1) show almost no change, while a more significant decrease in wavenumber is observed on BiVO4 (1640 cm−1). This suggests that FeOOH has a lower affinity for GLAD adsorption but a better desorption capacity. The infrared test results show that FeOOH is more effective in adsorbing the terminal hydroxyl groups of GLY and can desorb GLAD in a timely manner, which may be the reason for the higher yield of GLAD as the main oxidation product when FeOOH/BiVO4 is used as a catalyst. The Electrochemical Quartz Crystal Microbalance (EQCM) is a sensitive experimental technique that enables simultaneous measurement of both mass and frequency changes occurring on the material surface, thereby establishing an explicit correlation between these two parameters. Subsequent analysis utilizing EQCM has provided supplementary evidence that corroborates the remarkable adsorption efficacy of FeOOH/BiVO4 composite photoanodes towards GLY, as well as their exceptional desorption performance concerning GLAD. For the EQCM measurements, BiVO4, FeOOH, and FeOOH/BiVO4 were directly synthesized onto conductive quartz crystal substrates with an area of 0.5 cm2, acting as the working electrode. A platinum wire and an Ag/AgCl electrode served as the counter and reference electrodes, respectively. The EQCM was used to monitor the mass change when the electrode was exposed to 0.1 M Na2SO4 with or without 0.1 M glycerol or glyceraldehyde. The adsorbed amount was determined from the frequency shift (Δf) using the Sauerbrey equation: Δf = -2f0 2Δm/[A(µρ)0.5], where f0 is the fundamental frequency of the quartz crystal, A is the geometric area of the electrode, μ is the shear modulus of quartz, and ρ is the density of quartz. According to Fig. 5c, the frequency variations of BiVO4, FeOOH, and FeOOH/BiVO4 in the 0.1 M Na2SO4 solution are found to be insignificant. Conversely, upon addition of 0.1 M GLY to the solution, the BiVO4 photoanode displays an initial negative frequency at a potential of −0.2 V vs. RHE. This phenomenon can be attributed to the spontaneous adsorption of GLY on the surface of BiVO4, leading to an increment in the mass of the photoanode and consequently causing a negative shift in frequency [49,50]. In comparison, it is evident that FeOOH and FeOOH/BiVO4 exhibit significantly enhanced negative frequency changes following the introduction of GLY, and FeOOH/BiVO4 displays the most prominent negative shift. These observations suggest a considerably higher degree of GLY adsorption on FeOOH/BiVO4, aligning precisely with the findings obtained from the previous FT-IR analysis. Notably, upon the addition of 0.1 M GLAD to a 0.1 M Na2SO4 solution, as demonstrated in Fig. 5d, the initial frequencies of FeOOH and FeOOH/BiVO4 exhibit a marked reduction compared to that of BiVO4. These findings suggest a diminished adsorption capacity of GLAD on FeOOH and FeOOH/BiVO4 relative to that on BiVO4. The substantial difference observed in the initial frequencies of FeOOH and FeOOH/BiVO4 in different solutions highlights their pronounced affinity towards GLY adsorption and comparatively lower affinity towards the oxidation product, GLAD. An analysis was also conducted on the reaction process involving GLY and its oxidation products on the photoanodes. Based on the data from Fig. 5e, it is evident that the composite photoanode displays an elevated photocurrent when exposed to GLY, whereas the photocurrent observed in GLAD closely approximates that of water. Even though the photoanode demonstrates an increased oxidative photocurrent within the GLA (the byproduct originating from the overoxidation of GLAD), a substantial portion of the GLAD derived via GLY oxidation desorbs from the catalyst surface, leading to a reduced formation of C1 and C2 products through the overoxidation of GLAD. Conversely, the oxidation of DHA manifests a marginally higher oxidative photocurrent in contrast to GLAD, suggesting that the predominant source of the C1 and C2 products could be attributed to the oxidation of DHA. Additionally, Fig. S6 reveals a counterintuitive trend: the production of FA diminishes as the voltage increases. This behavior is elucidated by examining Fig. 5e, which illustrates that FA, during the anodic surface reaction, exhibits an oxidative photocurrent that is only surpassed by that of GLY. This suggests that FA possesses significant catalytic activity on the photoanode surface. Moreover, we performed carbon balance calculations before and after the reaction, with the findings presented in Fig. S15 (detailed data provided in Table S4). It is observed that across various voltages, the initial carbon content, amounting to 0.024 mol, shows a decreasing trend when measured by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) as the voltage is stepped up. Drawing from the research on glycerol catalytic oxidation products by JEFFERY D Z et al. [51], it is inferred that the majority of the carbon loss is converted into CO2 and carbonates. Consequently, the over-oxidation of FA into CO2 and carbonates is identified as the primary cause for the diminished selectivity of FA at elevated voltages. Based on the research findings, we have postulated a plausible GLY oxidation pathway. As shown in Fig. 5f, during the photoelectrochemical hydrogen production process on FeOOH/BiVO4, GLY oxidation leads to the formation of GLAD (major pathway) and DHA (minor pathway) through dehydrogenation reactions. Specifically, DHA facilely undergoes conversion into C1 and C2 products via the cleavage of C–C bonds, whereas GLAD exhibits a relative stability and has the capacity to accrue under specific reaction conditions. However, maintaining high selectivity for GLAD at elevated GLY conversion rates remains a challenge. 3.6 Reaction mechanism of PEC glycerol oxidation. Presently, investigations pertaining to the PEC oxidation of GLY predominantly encompass two oxidation pathways: direct oxidation facilitated by photogenerated holes (h+) and indirect oxidation mediated through hydroxyl radicals (·OH). To acquire a more profound comprehension of the operational principles of composite photoanodes within the context of the GLY reaction, experiments involving room-temperature electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) and radical quenching were performed. As illustrated in Fig. 6 a–c, both BiVO4 and FeOOH/BiVO4 manifest signal peaks corresponding to hydroxyl radicals and GLY radicals in solutions comprising 0.1 M Na2SO4, 0.1 M pristine GLY, and their amalgamated form. This observation suggests that both the OER and the GOR potentially involve the consumption of photogenerated holes. Importantly, the intensity of the radical signal peaks of FeOOH/BiVO4 exceeds that of BiVO4 across all electrolytes, implying the outstanding photoelectrochemical capabilities of FeOOH/BiVO4, consistent with the photocurrent data (as depicted in Fig. 1a). Previous studies suggest that both h+ and ·OH possess specific oxidation abilities, facilitating the generation of GLY radicals. Consequently, we performed experiments on radical quenching to validate the pivotal involvement of photogenerated holes and radicals in the PEC glycerol oxidation process. As depicted in Fig. 6d, the introduction of tert-butanol (TBA, a hydroxyl radical (·OH) scavenger) into the reaction resulted in a slight increase in glycerol conversion compared to normal conditions. This is because the addition of a ·OH scavenger reduces the competitive water oxidation reaction on the catalyst surface, thereby exposing more active sites for the glycerol oxidation process to proceed. The role of ·OH in glycerol conversion was investigated. As shown in Fig. S16, when the hydroxyl radical scavenger (TBA) was added, a decrease in GLAD selectivity was observed, along with the formation of over-oxidized products such as GLA and FA. The fluorescence intensity comparison and the subsequent catalytic experiments collectively suggest a key point: the adsorbed ·OH radicals on the FeOOH-20/BiVO4 surface contribute to a more controlled oxidation environment. This controlled environment is essential for the selective oxidation of glycerol to GLAD, thus preventing its over-oxidation to other products (Fig. S17). This indicates that the adsorbed ·OH radicals play an important role in preventing the over-oxidation of GLAD, ensuring the desired product selectivity and highlighting the catalyst's ability to moderate the oxidative potential of ·OH radicals. In contrast, the introduction of Na2SO3 (as a hole (h+) scavenger) still resulted in a small amount of glycerol being converted, indicating the presence of a weaker electrocatalytic oxidation of glycerol on the photoanode surface. Based on these findings, we conclude that the photoelectrochemical oxidation of GLY is a direct oxidation pathway primarily controlled by photogenerated holes. Fig. 6e summarizes the reaction pathways of glycerol oxidation in this study, where photogenerated holes quickly migrate to the FeOOH surface through Bi-O-Fe bonds at the heterojunction, where glycerol and its oxidation byproducts undergo adsorption and desorption processes on these reactive, low-coordination Fe species surfaces. Variations in the distribution of BiOFe active sites on different photoanode surfaces, as well as differences in the adsorption and desorption characteristics of glycerol and various oxidation products on different photoanode surfaces, lead to fluctuations in glycerol conversion rates and the preferential formation of GLAD on different photoanode surfaces. 3.7 Density functional theory calculations Employing DFT calculations as the analytical approach, an in-depth scrutiny was conducted into the adsorption characteristics of GLY molecules and their ensuing oxidation byproducts, GLAD, at the interface of dissimilar materials, aiming to elucidate the ramifications of FeOOH/BiVO4 on the underlying mechanism governing the oxidative processes of GLY through photoelectrochemical means. Based on the XPS spectrum depicted in Fig. 3 for FeOOH/BiVO4, it can be deduced that the composite photoanode exhibits distinct Fe sites, namely, those bonded to Bi and those not bonded to Bi. Hence, as a primary step, we conducted simulations to ascertain the adsorption energies of GLY molecules at distinct Fe sites within the heterojunction model, aiming to identify the authentic reactive center among the Fe sites. Throughout the simulation procedure, to replicate the genuine amorphous configuration of FeOOH, certain surface hydroxyl groups were eliminated to create a model representing Fe not bonded to Bi, as illustrated in Fig. S18a. Fig. 7 illustrates the Bi-O-Fe coordination sites engendered at the BiVO4 and FeOOH interphase, Fe2+ sites not bonded to Bi, as well as the adsorption energy of GLY on pure BiVO4. Observations reveal that the adsorption energy of GLY on the Bi-O-Fe site (with Eads at −2.01 eV, Fig. 7a) notably surpasses the adsorption energy of GLY on the Fe2+ site devoid of Bi bonding (−1.08 eV, Fig. 7b), thus suggesting that the Bi-O-Fe site engendered by the heterojunction interface serves as the crucial site for GLY adsorption. The introduction of unsaturated Bi-O-Fe sites through heterojunctions enhances the adsorption energy on the surface of the FeOOH/BiVO4 composite photoanode for GLY molecules, thereby elevating its GLY conversion efficiency. Of particular significance is the fact that the binding strength of GLY onto pure BiVO4 registers as the least potent, at −0.87 eV (Fig. 7c), providing additional evidence for the advantage of employing heterojunction engineering in the development of composite photoanodes for GLY transformation. Considering the presence of both terminal and intermediary hydroxyl groups within GLY molecules, the competitive adsorption dynamics between these two types of hydroxyl groups might lead to differences in the preferential formation of catalytic products. Therefore, a more comprehensive investigation was conducted to examine the adsorption energies related to terminal and intermediary hydroxyl groups present in GLY molecules adsorbed on FeOOH/BiVO4. From Fig. S18b–d, it can be observed that the adsorption energy of the intermediary hydroxyl group of GLY on the composite photoanode of FeOOH/BiVO4 (Eabs = −0.99 eV) is significantly lower than the adsorption energy of the terminal hydroxyl group of GLY on the same surface (Eabs = −2.01 eV). Subsequently, we hypothesize that during the initial reaction process of GLY, the FeOOH/BiVO4 photoanode surface exhibits a proclivity for selectively adsorbing terminal hydroxyl groups, thereby catalyzing their conversion into CO. In addition, the desorption capabilities of different intermediate products on the photoanode also affect the selectivity of the products. Consequently, distinct calculations were conducted to determine the adsorption energies of GLAD on Bi-O-Fe (Fig. S18c) and pristine BiVO4 (Fig. S18d). The research findings demonstrate that Bi-O-Fe exhibits the lowest adsorption energy towards GLAD (with Eads at −0.49 eV), which is below that of pristine BiVO4 for GLAD (Eads at −0.94 eV). Based on these findings, we can infer that GLY molecules predominantly attach as terminal hydroxyl groups on the active sites of Bi-O-Fe on the FeOOH/BiVO4 surface, subsequently undergoing oxidation to generate GLAD. As GLAD is more prone to desorption from the photoanode surface, the composite photoanode demonstrates increased GLY conversion efficiency and selectivity towards GLAD. Fig. 7d displays the density of states (DOS) spectra of FeOOH/BiVO4, contrasted with pristine BiVO4 (Fig. S19), revealing a considerable narrowing of the bandgap width. This narrowing results in a pronounced enhancement in the electrical conductivity of the composite photoanode. With the reduced bandgap width and enhanced conductivity, the composite facilitates swift carrier migration and more effective utilization of light energy. These improvements provide increased kinetic driving forces for glycerol conversion, propelling the process towards higher efficiency. The experimental results and computational simulations presented here illuminate the photocatalytic oxidation mechanism of GLY on the FeOOH/BiVO4 composite photoanode. The catalytic site for glycerol-assisted GLAD formation is intricately structured by the Bi-O-Fe moiety, arising from the synergistic interaction between FeOOH and BiVO4. The entirety of the GLY oxidation pathway is orchestrated by the photogenerated holes. As shown in Fig. 7e, the initiation of the chemical reaction involves GLY adsorption at the Bi-O-Fe locus. Upon exposure to light, the photogenerated holes migrate towards the electron-abundant zone on the surface, with additional promotion of hole migration facilitated by Bi-O-Fe. Photogenerated holes, which are endowed with robust oxidative prowess, instigate the spontaneous dehydrogenation process of the terminal carbon atom within GLY molecules anchored onto the FeOOH/BiVO4 interface, thereby engendering the formation of carbon radicals. Subsequently, the generated H* undergoes oxidation to a proton by the photogenerated hole. Simultaneously, the adjacent hydrogen atoms linked to the hydroxyl moiety attached to the carbon radical are eliminated by the holes, resulting in the synthesis of GLAD[52]. This generated GLAD swiftly disengages from the amalgamated photoanode, effectively impeding any subsequent oxidative processes. 4 Conclusions The conversion of glycerol PEC into high-value-added products holds substantial implications for both environmental preservation and industrial advancement. Through judicious design and controlled construction of surface-active sites tailored to adsorb and activate reactant molecules in synchronization with the activation phase, it is feasible to engineer high-performance composite photoanodes. This investigation involves the deposition of FeOOH co-catalyst onto the BiVO4 surface, showcasing that the Bi-O-Fe sites induced by the heterojunction of BiVO4 and FeOOH enable the successful and highly selective conversion of GLY into valuable GLAD. The following key conclusions can be drawn from this study: (1) At the FeOOH/BiVO4 interface, the Bi-O-Fe sites are recognized as pivotal locations for the specific transformation of GLY into GLAD in PEC. These Bi-O-Fe sites not only act as primary reactive centers catalyzing the adsorption and conversion of glycerol hydroxyl clusters but also serve as hole-trapping reservoirs, accelerating the breaking of C–H bonds to produce GLAD. They exhibit excellent desorption capability for GLAD, ensuring superior product selectivity. (2) Studies on the dynamics of photocurrent demonstrate that the formation of a p-n junction by FeOOH and BiVO4 markedly amplifies the effectiveness of surface charge separation, leading to a collaborative enhancement in both the photoelectrochemical performance and the GLY oxidation capacity of the composite material. (3) Examination of the thermodynamics of the photoanode indicates that FeOOH/BiVO4 demonstrates distinctive adsorption affinity towards the terminal hydroxyl group of GLY and exceptional desorption proficiency towards GLAD. This factor stands as pivotal among the rationales underpinning the exceptional efficacy of the composite photoanode in preferentially transforming GLY to GLAD. (4) By means of the collaborative influence of FeOOH and BiVO4, a proficient transformation from GLY to GLAD has been successfully realized, sustaining a selectivity exceeding 60 % over an extended duration, yielding as high as 709 mmol m−2 h−1. coredata.dc:description: Heterojunction engineering is crucial for converting glycerol into valuable organic compounds via photoelectrochemistry, but controlling the structure precisely to enhance conversion efficiency remains challenging. In this study, we effectively created a compound photoanode with unique active regions by growing amorphous FeOOH co-catalysts on BiVO4. The results revealed that the Fe2+ ions located on the surface of the co-catalyst FeOOH facilitate the glycerol transformation process, whereas the electron-rich Bi-O-Fe sites contribute significantly to the preferential transformation of glycerol into glyceraldehyde. These sites not only serve as primary reactive centers, catalyzing the adsorption and conversion of glycerol hydroxyl clusters, but also act as repositories for trapping holes. This dual function accelerates the breaking of CH bonds to generate glycerol aldehyde and exhibits excellent desorption capacity, ensuring exceptional product selectivity. This led to exceptional glyceraldehyde production (709mmol m-2 h−1) compared to pristine BiVO4, showcasing a 14.98-fold increase.

coredata.dc:title: Improved glyceraldehyde generation through FeOOH co-catalysts-modified BiVO4 featuring Bi-O-Fe active sites for photoelectrocatalytic glycerol oxidation
